newsitem.title: CANADA: CWB chief "concerned" on possible grain price war.
newsitem.headline: CWB chief "concerned" on possible grain price war.

text.p: A global grain price war may be looming after the European Union reintroduced wheat and barley export subsidies last month, sparking concerns the United States may not be far behind in reviving subsidies, Canadian Wheat Board chief commissioner Lorne Hehn said on Thursday.

"We are very concerned about the possibility of another full scale trade war in wheat and barley and to this extent, we met recently with our counterparts in the EU to discuss government intervention in the market," Hehn said in a speech to the United Grain Growers Ltd annual meeting here.

Canada and Australia, among other wheat exporting nations, campaigned against European and U.S. grain export subsidies for years before those subsidies were suspended last year due to dwindling world grain stocks and soaring grain prices.
But bumper grain crops this year have sent wheat and corn prices plummeting since the summer, creating a much more competitive situation for exporters.

World wheat output in the current marketing year was forecast to be the second largest on record at 573 million tonnes with much of the increase seen in major importing regions such as China, Brazil, and North Africa, Hehn said.
"We have once again gone from a sellers' market to a buyers' market in a very short time frame," Hehn said.
Hehn said the EU reintroduced export subsidies equal to C$35 a tonne in wheat and C$50 for barley early in October.
"Of course, the unknown in all of this is whether or not the U.S. will reinstate its Export Enhancement Program (export subsidy)," Hehn said.
Asked if he thought the U.S. would restart EEP subsidies suspended last year, Hehn told Reuters: "It's political, and the Republicans are on record as supporting these things."
World wheat demand this year was expected to be 89 million tonnes, Hehn said.
"Argentina's 15-million-tonne crop along with the record Australian 21-million-tonne wheat crop is now causing intense competition in the January forward shipping months," he added.
Hehn said China was expected to remain the CWB's top milling wheat client and after two years of market development, the CWB made its first ever durum sale to Iran recently, Hehn said.

"With record barley production on the Prairies, a barley crop of 53 million tonnes in the EU and Australia's barley harvest now under way, competition in feed barley is expected to be fierce," Hehn said.
Statistics Canada on Oct 8 forecast barley output at a record 15.992 million tonnes, up 23 percent from the previous year's production of 13.035 million tonnes.
"Targeting markets that are not traditional users of Canadian feed barley is a priority," he said.
South Korea recently reduced feed barley import tariffs, allowing the CWB to conclude its first ever sale there, Hehn said.
